values.title: ffmpeg 3.1 deprecation warnings on homebrew

content.raw:
ffmpeg 3.1 is now the default version in homebrew, and it has deprecated some things that are used in gazebo.

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/103/warnings8Result/

~~~
/usr/local/Cellar/ffmpeg/3.1/include/libavformat/avformat.h:880:21: note: 'codec' has been explicitly marked deprecated here
    AVCodecContext *codec;
                    ^
~~~

~~~
/usr/local/Cellar/ffmpeg/3.1/include/libavcodec/avcodec.h:4753:5: note: 'avcodec_decode_video2' has been explicitly marked deprecated here
int avcodec_decode_video2(AVCodecContext *avctx, AVFrame *picture,
    ^


/usr/local/Cellar/ffmpeg/3.1/include/libavcodec/avcodec.h:4704:5: note: 'avcodec_decode_audio4' has been explicitly marked deprecated here
int avcodec_decode_audio4(AVCodecContext *avctx, AVFrame *frame,
    ^
~~~
We can try to depend on something old like [homebrew/versions/ffmpeg28](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-versions/blob/master/ffmpeg28.rb), or we can upgrade to the new interfaces if they exist in the versions of `libavcodec` and `libavformat` used on trusty.
content.html:
ffmpeg 3.1 is now the default version in homebrew, and it has deprecated some things that are used in gazebo.

  • http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/103/warnings8Result/
/usr/local/Cellar/ffmpeg/3.1/include/libavformat/avformat.h:880:21: note: 'codec' has been explicitly marked deprecated here
    AVCodecContext *codec;
                    ^

/usr/local/Cellar/ffmpeg/3.1/include/libavcodec/avcodec.h:4753:5: note: 'avcodec_decode_video2' has been explicitly marked deprecated here
int avcodec_decode_video2(AVCodecContext *avctx, AVFrame *picture,
    ^


/usr/local/Cellar/ffmpeg/3.1/include/libavcodec/avcodec.h:4704:5: note: 'avcodec_decode_audio4' has been explicitly marked deprecated here
int avcodec_decode_audio4(AVCodecContext *avctx, AVFrame *frame,
    ^

We can try to depend on something old like homebrew/versions/ffmpeg28, or we can upgrade to the new interfaces if they exist in the versions of libavcodec and libavformat used on trusty.

values.title: gzclient crashes with assertion failed when using XFCE after restoring minimized window

content.raw:
Hi,
When using Gazebo 7.2.0-1~trusty using the XFCE window manager, I can start gazebo nicely and play around with it. However when minimizing the window and bringing it back to focus, I get the following error:
```
Qt has caught an exception thrown from an event handler. Throwing
exceptions from an event handler is not supported in Qt. You must
reimplement QApplication::notify() and catch all exceptions there.

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'Ogre::ItemIdentityException'
  what():  OGRE EXCEPTION(4:ItemIdentityException): A camera with the name default::gzclient_camera(1)_selection_buffer already exists in OctreeSceneManager::createCamera at /build/buildd/ogre-1.8-1.8.1+dfsg/PlugIns/OctreeSceneManager/src/OgreOctreeSceneManager.cpp (line 372)
```

The backtrace is as follows:
```
(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007ffff6592c37 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
#1  0x00007ffff6596028 in __GI_abort () at abort.c:89
#2  0x00007ffff6b97535 in __gnu_cxx::__verbose_terminate_handler() () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6
#3  0x00007ffff6b956d6 in ?? () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6
#4  0x00007ffff6b95703 in std::terminate() () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6
#5  0x00007ffff6b95976 in __cxa_rethrow () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6
#6  0x00007ffff71bb596 in QEventLoop::exec (this=this@entry=0x7fffffffc690, flags=...) at kernel/qeventloop.cpp:218
#7  0x00007ffff71c0b79 in QCoreApplication::exec () at kernel/qcoreapplication.cpp:1225
#8  0x00007ffff277e37c in QApplication::exec () at kernel/qapplication.cpp:3828
#9  0x00007ffff7655e5b in gazebo::gui::run (_argc=_argc@entry=1, _argv=_argv@entry=0x7fffffffc8b8) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.2.0/gazebo/gui/GuiIface.cc:315
#10 0x000000000040152a in main (_argc=1, _argv=0x7fffffffc8b8) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.2.0/gazebo/gui/main.cc:25
```

I couldn't find any related issues yet. My system is pretty standard (I think), Ubuntu 14.04, using XFCE. It does not happen when using the standard Ubuntu window manager.


Please let me know if you need any further information.

Best, Tobias

values.title: Complete the move to material design

values.title: segfault when calling ipopt virtual method

content.html:
the following very simple plugin crashes:

#include <stdio.h> #include <stdlib.h> #include <string.h> #include <string> #include <IpIpoptApplication.hpp> #include <gazebo/gazebo.hh>

namespace gazebo { class myGazeboPlugin : public WorldPlugin { public: myGazeboPlugin() : WorldPlugin(), r(false) { }

    void Load(physics::WorldPtr _world, sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)
    {

        Ipopt::RegisteredOptions* a = new Ipopt::RegisteredOptions;
        a->SetRegisteringCategory("Undocumented");

    }
};

extern "C" GZ_COMMON_VISIBLE gazebo::WorldPlugin RegisterPlugin(); gazebo::WorldPlugin RegisterPlugin() { return new myGazeboPlugin(); } }

note: 1. SetRegisteringCategory is a virtual method 2. by making SetRegisteringCategory a non virtual method and rebuild ipopt the segfault goes away 3. by making "a" a real object (so not a pointer) the segfault does not occur calling the method but occurs in the Ipopt::RegisteredOptions* a = new Ipopt::RegisteredOptions; in a subsequent instantiation of the plugin object. think this happen due to the nature of the RegisterOptions itself that require to be managed through pointers.

request: is there a way to correctly use ipopt inside a gazebo plugin?

values.title: Laser minimum range incorrect behavior

content.raw:
Rays created by a laser sensor start at a the sensor position with an offset that corresponds to the min_range SDF parameter. The problem is that if the sensor is closed to another surface element, its rays will go through that element (see issue #1564). This pull request fixes this issue and also makes sure that rays are not displayed when their length is below min_range.

A solution was proposed in pull request #2320. A better alternative would use a `<self_collide>` flag. See comments in pull request #2320.
content.html:
Rays created by a laser sensor start at a the sensor position with an offset that corresponds to the min_range SDF parameter. The problem is that if the sensor is closed to another surface element, its rays will go through that element (see issue #1564). This pull request fixes this issue and also makes sure that rays are not displayed when their length is below min_range.

A solution was proposed in pull request #2320. A better alternative would use a <self_collide> flag. See comments in pull request #2320.

values.title: Translation mode not working on unselected objects if topic viewer is open

content.raw:
If I launch a world and select the translation mouse mode, I can click and drag objects around without having to have them highlighted first.

However, if I open a topic viewer, even though translation mode is still selected, I can't drag objects around anymore - it just pans the view around as if I were in selection mode. In order to translate objects I have to switch to selection mode, select them, and switch back to translation mode.


Closing the topic viewer doesn't restore the original behaviour.

I am using gazebo 7.2.0 on ubuntu 14.04 through a virtual machine on osx.

Steps to reproduce:

1. launch gazebo. add a block. the block translates as expected.

2. open a topic viewer on ~/log/control. try to translate the block, but the view pans.
content.html:
If I launch a world and select the translation mouse mode, I can click and drag objects around without having to have them highlighted first.

However, if I open a topic viewer, even though translation mode is still selected, I can't drag objects around anymore - it just pans the view around as if I were in selection mode. In order to translate objects I have to switch to selection mode, select them, and switch back to translation mode.

Closing the topic viewer doesn't restore the original behaviour.

I am using gazebo 7.2.0 on ubuntu 14.04 through a virtual machine on osx.

Steps to reproduce:

  1. launch gazebo. add a block. the block translates as expected.

  2. open a topic viewer on ~/log/control. try to translate the block, but the view pans.

values.title: Unexpected behavior when a model is attached to an animated parent

content.raw:
A joint is attaching two models. One model is animated with a PoseAnimation and the other expected to follow the other one. Using a fixed joint, we can clearly see that the transform between the two models is not kept constant.

Tried with ODE and Bullet in Gazebo 7.3.0

values.title: Visual bounding box calculation ignore gui visuals

content.raw:
Bounding box calculation currently [ignores gui visuals](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2e88a7f46c755cdcaf3ed7abfe56a64778560f87/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Visual.cc-1950) like inertia, wrench, selection objects, etc. This also means that calling `Visual::GetBoundingBox()` on a gui visual will always return incorrect results (empty box).

Some ideas to improve the check:

1. If visual already has the `GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI` flag then don't ignore child gui visuals

1. Add optional argument to `Visual::GetBoundingBox()` to ignore certain visual types
content.html:
Bounding box calculation currently ignores gui visuals like inertia, wrench, selection objects, etc. This also means that calling Visual::GetBoundingBox() on a gui visual will always return incorrect results (empty box).

Some ideas to improve the check:

  1. If visual already has the GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI flag then don't ignore child gui visuals

  2. Add optional argument to Visual::GetBoundingBox() to ignore certain visual types

values.title: Handful of test cases failing on Ubuntu 14.04

content.raw:
I recently installed Gazebo 8 from source on Ubuntu 14.04, with the intention of contributing some bugfixes.  Before I make any changes, I'd like to get all the test cases passing, which is where I'm running into trouble.  The following test cases are still failing:

    133 - UNIT_DataLogger_TEST (OTHER_FAULT)
    165 - UNIT_ApplyWrenchDialog_TEST (Failed)
    331 - PERFORMANCE_set_world_pose (Failed)
    485 - INTEGRATION_factory (Failed)
    493 - INTEGRATION_heightmap (OTHER_FAULT)
    531 - EXAMPLE_examples_build (Failed)
    573 - REGRESSION_config-pkgconfig (Failed)

When I try to run the last two (531 and 573), cmake complains about not being able to find gazebo.  I think that's happening because I installed Gazebo under /home/[username], rather than /usr/local.  In the case of test 531, if I change the cmake command in examples_build.cc (line 78) to correctly set the CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH, the test succeeds.  Likewise, if I correctly set the PKG_CONFIG_PATH environment variable before running test 573, it will also succeed.  Does this indicate that I made a mistake when installing Gazebo?

The error message for test 331 indicates that the test took longer than expected (approximately 30 seconds, rather than 15).  I don't think there's anything I can do about that, but I would be happy to be corrected.

Test 133 fails intermittently.  I've included the output below.

As for the other tests (165, 485, 493), I'm stumped.  Their output is below.

Test 133: [output](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/a5bc9ff167ab7e6baec9043a38214690) -- [UNIT_DataLogger_TEST.xml](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/bed312dc6869c14c3c6f607e3f1913f7)

Test 165: [output](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/379937d0a5fd447aff72080c572712c9) -- [UNIT_ApplyWrenchDialog_TEST.xml](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/b23858dee46f3628017acb9bfa749286)

Test 331: [output](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/1e9f0f0d62e7863329fd488f5f02ba2d) -- [PERFORMANCE_set_world_pose.xml](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/0422df4b63099ab5f7947afb0a4e0dd7)

Test 485: [output](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/026219913c260609b4094026407dd786#file-integration_factory-out-L65) -- [INTEGRATION_factory.xml](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/9a36bed953a97a0ed69ee74fe8f3e27f)

Test 493: [output](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/3ee66103cebcf97a46754be3a7b7c145) -- [INTEGRATION_heightmap.xml](https://gist.github.com/ccrean/a49046f924a91c0d193c45351bb352ef)

Any help or suggestions would be much appreciated.

values.title: Reset is never called for some plugin types

content.raw:
For most plugin types, we offer three virtual functions which can be overriden: `Load` (pure virtual), `Init` and `Reset`. But for some plugin types, the `Reset` functions are never called. See the summary below:

| Plugin Type | Load | Init | Reset |
| --------------- | ------ | ---- | ------- |
| [World](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/common/Plugin.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Plugin.hh-231) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/physics/World.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-1602) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/physics/World.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-1606) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/physics/World.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-1291) |
| [Model](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/common/Plugin.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Plugin.hh-257) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/physics/Model.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Model.cc-1125) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/physics/Model.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Model.cc-1143) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/physics/Model.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Model.cc-699) |
| [Sensor](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/common/Plugin.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Plugin.hh-285) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/sensors/Sensor.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Sensor.cc-322) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/sensors/Sensor.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Sensor.cc-323) | exists, but not used |
| [System](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/common/Plugin.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Plugin.hh-314) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/gazebo_shared.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#gazebo_shared.cc-78) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/gazebo_shared.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#gazebo_shared.cc-97) | exists, but not used |
| [Visual](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/common/Plugin.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Plugin.hh-343) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Visual.cc-3059) | used [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Visual.cc-3063) and [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Visual.cc-3038) | exists, but not used |
| [GUI](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/gui/GuiPlugin.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#GuiPlugin.hh-25) | [used](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/gui/RenderWidget.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#RenderWidget.cc-298) | doesn't exist | doesn't exist |
content.html:
For most plugin types, we offer three virtual functions which can be overriden: Load (pure virtual), Init and Reset. But for some plugin types, the Reset functions are never called. See the summary below:

Plugin Type Load Init Reset
World used used used
Model used used used
Sensor used used exists, but not used
System used used exists, but not used
Visual used used here and here exists, but not used
GUI used doesn't exist doesn't exist

values.title: gzclient creates and destroys a lot of threads after startup

content.raw:
When running `gzclient` in `gdb` it creates several threads during start up. But after that it creates a thread and destroys it again for the next 25-30 seconds. In this time it goes through > 180 threads. Each of the them is only alive for a fraction of a second.

This is on Xenial with the Debian package 7.3.1 of Gazebo.
content.html:
When running gzclient in gdb it creates several threads during start up. But after that it creates a thread and destroys it again for the next 25-30 seconds. In this time it goes through > 180 threads. Each of the them is only alive for a fraction of a second.

This is on Xenial with the Debian package 7.3.1 of Gazebo.

values.title: Computing CoG of a model

content.raw:
I tried to get the CoG of a model by [adding the inertial](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/physics/Inertial.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Inertial.cc-243) of each link. 
It happens that the inertial's pose does not take in account the link's pose in the model.
So it uses mostly a link.inertial.cog.pose of (0,0,0) and don't take in account the links distances.
It was supposed to be like that?
May be the case to add a method that gives the CoG of a model, or of a set of links.
content.html: I tried to get the CoG of a model by adding the inertial of each link. It happens that the inertial's pose does not take in account the link's pose in the model. So it uses mostly a link.inertial.cog.pose of (0,0,0) and don't take in account the links distances. It was supposed to be like that? May be the case to add a method that gives the CoG of a model, or of a set of links.

values.title: Logical camera missing from msgs.cc in gazebo 7.3.1

content.raw:
I am using gazebo 7.3.1 from packages because I want to use it with ROS.

When I run logical_camera.world, I get the following warnings:

```
[Wrn] [msgs.cc:1702] Conversion of sensor type[logical_camera] not suppported.
[Wrn] [msgs.cc:1702] Conversion of sensor type[logical_camera] not suppported.
[Wrn] [msgs.cc:1702] Conversion of sensor type[logical_camera] not suppported.
[Wrn] [msgs.cc:1702] Conversion of sensor type[logical_camera] not suppported.
```

I believe it's because these lines are missing in v7.3.1: #!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/msgs/msgs.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#msgs.cc-1810


At least I am still able to make use of the sensor if I already know the topic name (but I think if I were to try to access it through a link it wouldn't work)

I believe it's because these lines are missing in v7.3.1: #!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/msgs/msgs.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#msgs.cc-1810

At least I am still able to make use of the sensor if I already know the topic name (but I think if I were to try to access it through a link it wouldn't work)

values.title: GLWidget recursively triggering paintEvent

content.raw:
While looking at an unrelated performance problem I noticed that the `GLWidget::paintEvent` method is being triggered repeatedly. Tens of times per millisecond. The following line seems to be responsible for that: #!/osrf/gazebo/src/7b569fa32ec75676c8c007286470635499d5f168/gazebo/gui/GLWidget.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#GLWidget.cc-290

I am not sure what the right fix for this.

values.title: Improve documentation on Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition

content.raw:
I'd say this point was discussed many times, but the documentation is not clear for me. 
After some tests and reviewing link's and ode's code, I had the follow impression:

- `ODELink::AddForce` and `ODELink::AddRelativeForce` applies force on the link's CoG (once they don't generate torque).
- `ODELink::AddForceAtRelativePosition` uses a relative position related to the link's CoG.
- ode's `dBodyAddRelForceAtRelPos` add a force in link's frame at position related to the link's CoG
- `ODELink::AddLinkForce` add a force in link's frame at a position related to the link's origin.

It seems to me that ode doesn't take in account the link's origin but only the link's CoG.
And Gazebo take both in account, but the documentation doesn't make it clear.
Is that right?
content.html:
I'd say this point was discussed many times, but the documentation is not clear for me. After some tests and reviewing link's and ode's code, I had the follow impression:

  • ODELink::AddForce and ODELink::AddRelativeForce applies force on the link's CoG (once they don't generate torque).
  • ODELink::AddForceAtRelativePosition uses a relative position related to the link's CoG.
  • ode's dBodyAddRelForceAtRelPos add a force in link's frame at position related to the link's CoG
  • ODELink::AddLinkForce add a force in link's frame at a position related to the link's origin.

It seems to me that ode doesn't take in account the link's origin but only the link's CoG. And Gazebo take both in account, but the documentation doesn't make it clear. Is that right?

values.title: RaySensor ray visualisations always start at origin of sensor

content.raw:
RaySensors have an option for the minimum range of the sensor. This is respected in the collisions (#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#MultiRayShape.cc-109) but not in the visuals.


No matter what the value of the minimum range, the visualisation of the sensor's rays always start at the origin of the sensor, not at the min range.



using 7.3.1

values.title: Flaky seg-fault during teardown in transport::IOManager

content.raw:
Since July 19th, I have been observing flaky seg-faults during teardown of a variety of tests with the console message:

~~~
terminate called after throwing an instance of
'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::thread_resource_error> >'
  what():  boost thread: trying joining itself: Resource deadlock avoided
~~~

I have seen many backtraces that implicate `transport::IOManager::Stop`, called from the destructor `~IOManager`. Some further details are in the gist:

* https://gist.github.com/scpeters/eef05f6e52f6d164a389c77b8ade35d9
content.html:
Since July 19th, I have been observing flaky seg-faults during teardown of a variety of tests with the console message:

terminate called after throwing an instance of
'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::thread_resource_error> >'
  what():  boost thread: trying joining itself: Resource deadlock avoided

I have seen many backtraces that implicate transport::IOManager::Stop, called from the destructor ~IOManager. Some further details are in the gist:

  • https://gist.github.com/scpeters/eef05f6e52f6d164a389c77b8ade35d9

values.title: error printing vectors with +-inf

content.raw:
I think that these lines should check if values are finite before applying `precision`: #!/osrf/gazebo/src/ca2a71952a3823494afe2aafe9b6996c40e31539/gazebo/math/Vector3.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Vector3.hh-326



Otherwise:

```

  math::Vector3 v=math::Vector3::Zero;
  v.z = std::numeric_limits<double>::max();
  std::cout << v << std::endl;

```



causes the following error:

```
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::math::rounding_error> >'
  what():  Error in function boost::math::round<d>(d): Value inf can not be represented in the target integer type.
Aborted (core dumped)

```

values.title: RaySensor rays should be blocked by objects inside min_range

content.raw:
The RaySensor currently returns `-Inf` if an object is detected below the minimum range of the sensor. However, it will override this `-Inf` reading if that ray hits an object within the valid range of the sensor. Physically this ray should be blocked, so it should not return any reading. I'm not sure if this is an issue in the physics or in the sensor class.

Here's an example with the hokuyo sensor and a small cylinder that fits entirely within the `min_range` area. Somehow it manages to see through the cylinder to see the part of the box that should be blocked.

![ray_sensor_unblocked_min_range.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2229666955-ray_sensor_unblocked_min_range.png)
content.html:
The RaySensor currently returns -Inf if an object is detected below the minimum range of the sensor. However, it will override this -Inf reading if that ray hits an object within the valid range of the sensor. Physically this ray should be blocked, so it should not return any reading. I'm not sure if this is an issue in the physics or in the sensor class.

Here's an example with the hokuyo sensor and a small cylinder that fits entirely within the min_range area. Somehow it manages to see through the cylinder to see the part of the box that should be blocked.

values.title: Default SphericalCoordinates frame should be East-North-Up (ENU)

content.raw:
The `<spherical_coordinates>` tag in sdformat declares itself to be using an East-North-Up (ENU) coordinate frame in [spherical_coordinates.sdf](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/4297678df05a60a4ee1663500c0f06c32d643f0a/sdf/1.6/spherical_coordinates.sdf?fileviewer=file-view-default#spherical_coordinates.sdf-31) (though rather indirectly, the language there should be clarified).

However, the gazebo `SphericalCoordinates` class appears to be using a West-South-Up (WSU) coordinate frame. I've committed a test in  da35d7c (branch `spherical_coordinates_enu`) showing the failure.
content.html:
The <spherical_coordinates> tag in sdformat declares itself to be using an East-North-Up (ENU) coordinate frame in spherical_coordinates.sdf (though rather indirectly, the language there should be clarified).

However, the gazebo SphericalCoordinates class appears to be using a West-South-Up (WSU) coordinate frame. I've committed a test in da35d7c (branch spherical_coordinates_enu) showing the failure.

values.title: Singularities in Euler Angles

content.raw:
I've noticed that when I specify the orientation of a body in a model file, if the pitch angle is PI/2, and I specify its value at a high precision, the ultimate orientation of the body when I load the model in Gazebo is incorrect.

The attached model file gives an example of what I'm seeing.  I've specified the orientation as [0, PI/2, -PI/4], which should align the body with the line y = -x, but that's not what I see when I load the model.  However, if I truncate the pitch angle by a few decimal places, the resulting orientation is correct.

This is definitely a minor issue, as it doesn't crop up unless I specify PI/2 to 15 or 16 decimal places.  However, that is the number of decimal places that I get by default when I generate a model file using a Ruby template.

I've done some work with Euler angles and the associated singularities in the past, so if nobody is looking at this already, I'd like to work on it.
content.html:
I've noticed that when I specify the orientation of a body in a model file, if the pitch angle is PI/2, and I specify its value at a high precision, the ultimate orientation of the body when I load the model in Gazebo is incorrect.

The attached model file gives an example of what I'm seeing. I've specified the orientation as [0, PI/2, -PI/4], which should align the body with the line y = -x, but that's not what I see when I load the model. However, if I truncate the pitch angle by a few decimal places, the resulting orientation is correct.

This is definitely a minor issue, as it doesn't crop up unless I specify PI/2 to 15 or 16 decimal places. However, that is the number of decimal places that I get by default when I generate a model file using a Ruby template.

I've done some work with Euler angles and the associated singularities in the past, so if nobody is looking at this already, I'd like to work on it.

values.title: Thread-safety of GetEntity from Sensor plugin OnUpdate()

content.raw:
We have a custom plugin, which is currently a Sensor plugin, that:

- gets the objects in contact with a specific link by name
- then uses the name to get the collision entity
- then get the link from the collision entity
- then apply a velocity to each of those contacting links

See:

- https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gear/src/23a3c2c359a294719b296e33644014b85712d556/osrf_gear/src/SideContactPlugin.cc?at=master&fileviewer=file-view-default#SideContactPlugin.cc-109:137
- https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gear/src/23a3c2c359a294719b296e33644014b85712d556/osrf_gear/src/SideContactPlugin.cc?at=master&fileviewer=file-view-default#SideContactPlugin.cc-143:149
- https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gear/src/23a3c2c359a294719b296e33644014b85712d556/osrf_gear/src/ConveyorBeltPlugin.cc?at=master&fileviewer=file-view-default#ConveyorBeltPlugin.cc-108:112

This will regularly trigger an assert in the `boost::shared_ptr` code, like this:

```
gzserver: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:653: typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::physics::Base; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::physics::Base*]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.

Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.
[Switching to Thread 0x7fff41658700 (LWP 5854)]
0x00007ffff68c3c37 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
56	../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c: No such file or directory.
(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007ffff68c3c37 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
#1  0x00007ffff68c7028 in __GI_abort () at abort.c:89
#2  0x00007ffff68bcbf6 in __assert_fail_base (fmt=0x7ffff6a0d3b8 "%s%s%s:%u: %s%sAssertion `%s' failed.\n%n", 
    assertion=assertion@entry=0x7ffff63136c0 "px != 0", file=file@entry=0x7ffff6313828 "/usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp", 
    line=line@entry=653, 
    function=function@entry=0x7ffff6348740 <_ZZNK5boost10shared_ptrIN6gazebo7physics4BaseEEptEvE19__PRETTY_FUNCTION__> "typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::physics::Base; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::physics::Base*]") at assert.c:92
#3  0x00007ffff68bcca2 in __GI___assert_fail (assertion=0x7ffff63136c0 "px != 0", 
    file=0x7ffff6313828 "/usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp", line=653, 
    function=0x7ffff6348740 <_ZZNK5boost10shared_ptrIN6gazebo7physics4BaseEEptEvE19__PRETTY_FUNCTION__> "typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::physics::Base; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::physics::Base*]") at assert.c:101
#4  0x00007ffff6261ae3 in boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::physics::Base>::operator-> (this=<optimized out>)
    at /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:653
#5  0x00007ffff6262848 in operator-> (this=<optimized out>) at /usr/include/c++/4.8/bits/basic_string.h:539
#6  gazebo::physics::Base::GetByName (this=0x19ec5a0, _name="drill_0::link::collision")
    at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/physics/Base.cc:291
#7  0x00007ffff62ec426 in gazebo::physics::World::GetByName (this=<optimized out>, _name="drill_0::link::collision")
    at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/physics/World.cc:997
#8  0x00007ffff62ec550 in gazebo::physics::World::GetEntity (this=<optimized out>, _name="drill_0::link::collision")
    at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/physics/World.cc:1026
#9  0x00007fff743a7de3 in gazebo::SideContactPlugin::CalculateContactingLinks (this=0xf369f0)
    at /home/william/universal_robot_ws/src/gear/osrf_gear/src/SideContactPlugin.cc:130
#10 0x00007fff745c71ea in gazebo::ConveyorBeltPlugin::OnUpdate (this=0xf369f0)
    at /home/william/universal_robot_ws/src/gear/osrf_gear/src/ConveyorBeltPlugin.cc:92
#11 0x00007ffff5e9a6d5 in operator() (this=<optimized out>) at /usr/include/boost/function/function_template.hpp:767
#12 gazebo::event::EventT<void ()>::Signal() (this=0x357f408)
    at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/common/Event.hh:370
#13 0x00007ffff5e97f7e in operator() (this=<optimized out>)
    at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/common/Event.hh:214
#14 gazebo::sensors::Sensor::Update (this=0x35741c0, _force=_force@entry=false)
    at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/sensors/Sensor.cc:246
#15 0x00007ffff5e9dba5 in gazebo::sensors::SensorManager::SensorContainer::Update (this=0xf15df0, _force=<optimized out>)
    at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc:585
#16 0x00007ffff5ea0d88 in gazebo::sensors::SensorManager::SensorContainer::RunLoop (this=0xf15df0)
    at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc:539
#17 0x00007ffff42f7a4a in ?? () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libboost_thread.so.1.54.0
#18 0x00007ffff55ce184 in start_thread (arg=0x7fff41658700) at pthread_create.c:312
#19 0x00007ffff698737d in clone () at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/clone.S:111
```

I believe this is because the Sensor plugin is running in a separate thread from the physics loop, so when our code calls `this->world->GetEntity(collision)`, it ends up iterating over the children of the world object and in a separate thread we have a plugin that is spawning new models periodically into the world.

My theory is that the `GetEntity` call ends up here:

- #!/osrf/gazebo/src/9bc8cb494795842b2b3e237687d95240c3b070d3/gazebo/physics/Base.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Base.cc-289:291

Where it is iterating over the world object's children using iterators. If in the other thread objects are being added to this same vector, then these iterators are probably becoming invalid, which eventually results in invalid iterators being interpreted as a boost shared pointer.

I think an appropriate response to this might be "sensor plugins are not thread safe with these calls; won't fix" and we're attempting to work around this now by redesigning the plugin in question to be a model plugin in order to avoid this issue. However, at @scpeters request, I'm opening this issue to keep track of it. Either there needs to be some high level documentation that mentions this thread non-safety and explains how the architecture of the different plugins affects what can be called from where. This documentation may exist, but I looked for a while and didn't find it (please point it out if I missed it).
content.html:
We have a custom plugin, which is currently a Sensor plugin, that:

  • gets the objects in contact with a specific link by name
  • then uses the name to get the collision entity
  • then get the link from the collision entity
  • then apply a velocity to each of those contacting links

I believe this is because the Sensor plugin is running in a separate thread from the physics loop, so when our code calls this->world->GetEntity(collision), it ends up iterating over the children of the world object and in a separate thread we have a plugin that is spawning new models periodically into the world.

My theory is that the GetEntity call ends up here:

  • #!/osrf/gazebo/src/9bc8cb494795842b2b3e237687d95240c3b070d3/gazebo/physics/Base.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Base.cc-289:291

Where it is iterating over the world object's children using iterators. If in the other thread objects are being added to this same vector, then these iterators are probably becoming invalid, which eventually results in invalid iterators being interpreted as a boost shared pointer.

I think an appropriate response to this might be "sensor plugins are not thread safe with these calls; won't fix" and we're attempting to work around this now by redesigning the plugin in question to be a model plugin in order to avoid this issue. However, at @scpeters request, I'm opening this issue to keep track of it. Either there needs to be some high level documentation that mentions this thread non-safety and explains how the architecture of the different plugins affects what can be called from where. This documentation may exist, but I looked for a while and didn't find it (please point it out if I missed it).

values.title: Symbol visibility issues on Linux

content.raw:
I'm working on a report of player failing to load the libgazebo_player plugin.  It looks like it's due to the fact that libgazebo_player references several symbols that aren't exported.  I put together a quick test to link a blank cpp file against libgazebo_player and got the following results:

```
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo_shared::addPlugin(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, std::vector<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::SystemPlugin>, std::allocator<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::SystemPlugin> > >&)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::init_world(boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::physics::World>)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::load()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::sensors::stop()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::sensors::load()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::Master::Init(unsigned short)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::sensors::init()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::Master::Master()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::sensors::fini()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::create_world(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::stop_worlds()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo_shared::setup(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, int, char**, std::vector<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::SystemPlugin>, std::allocator<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::SystemPlugin> > >&)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::load_world(boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::physics::World>, boost::shared_ptr<sdf::Element>)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::fini()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo_shared::printVersion()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::World::RunBlocking(unsigned int)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::Master::RunThread()'
```

The problem seems to be that the preprocessor definitions to enable symbol visibility are only being enabled in (WIN32) conditionals in gazebo/CMakeLists.txt, gazebo/physics/CMakeLists.txt, and gazebo/sensors/CMakeLists.txt.  There might be more cases of this, but the Player plugin only uses functions from those three.

The -DBUILDING_DLL* preprocessor definitions in the above files should either be moved out of WIN32 conditionals, or directly added to the CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS as in gazebo/rendering/CMakeLists.txt.  Ideally, all of the subdirectories would use the same approach.
content.html:
I'm working on a report of player failing to load the libgazebo_player plugin. It looks like it's due to the fact that libgazebo_player references several symbols that aren't exported. I put together a quick test to link a blank cpp file against libgazebo_player and got the following results:

/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo_shared::addPlugin(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, std::vector<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::SystemPlugin>, std::allocator<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::SystemPlugin> > >&)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::init_world(boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::physics::World>)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::load()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::sensors::stop()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::sensors::load()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::Master::Init(unsigned short)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::sensors::init()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::Master::Master()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::sensors::fini()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::create_world(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::stop_worlds()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo_shared::setup(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, int, char**, std::vector<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::SystemPlugin>, std::allocator<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::SystemPlugin> > >&)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::load_world(boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::physics::World>, boost::shared_ptr<sdf::Element>)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::fini()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo_shared::printVersion()'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::physics::World::RunBlocking(unsigned int)'
/usr/lib64/player/libgazebo_player.so: undefined reference to `gazebo::Master::RunThread()'

The problem seems to be that the preprocessor definitions to enable symbol visibility are only being enabled in (WIN32) conditionals in gazebo/CMakeLists.txt, gazebo/physics/CMakeLists.txt, and gazebo/sensors/CMakeLists.txt. There might be more cases of this, but the Player plugin only uses functions from those three.

The -DBUILDING_DLL* preprocessor definitions in the above files should either be moved out of WIN32 conditionals, or directly added to the CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS as in gazebo/rendering/CMakeLists.txt. Ideally, all of the subdirectories would use the same approach.

values.title: libgazebo_player should not be part of PKG_LIBRARIES

content.raw: The root CMakeLists.txt file assembles a list of gazebo's installed libraries called PKG_LIBRARIES, which is used in gazebo_config.cmake to locate all of the libraries required to link against gazebo.  libgazebo_player is different from the rest of the gazebo libraries in that it's a private plugin module meant to be consumed only by Player, not a library that exposes an API that can be used by non-Player projects.  As such, it doesn't really belong in the list of libraries exported to other projects.
content.html: The root CMakeLists.txt file assembles a list of gazebo's installed libraries called PKG_LIBRARIES, which is used in gazebo_config.cmake to locate all of the libraries required to link against gazebo. libgazebo_player is different from the rest of the gazebo libraries in that it's a private plugin module meant to be consumed only by Player, not a library that exposes an API that can be used by non-Player projects. As such, it doesn't really belong in the list of libraries exported to other projects.

values.title: OSX screen capture with transparency

content.raw:
On OSX the screen capture button will save an image that ignores transparency. For example, a black material  (0, 0, 0) with 50% transparency will be saved as black in the final image.

This problem may be related to Ogre 1.7.4.

See also `gazebo/gui/LaserVisual_TEST.cc`, which contains `#ifndef __APPLE__` statements.
content.html:
On OSX the screen capture button will save an image that ignores transparency. For example, a black material (0, 0, 0) with 50% transparency will be saved as black in the final image.

This problem may be related to Ogre 1.7.4.

See also gazebo/gui/LaserVisual_TEST.cc, which contains #ifndef __APPLE__ statements.

values.title: Color is not shown in gazebo from dae files

content.raw:
I am using ubuntu 14.04 and Gazebo 5 or gazebo 7, together with ros jade.
I am unable to display the colors of dae files when I load then into Gazebo via an sdf file.
The dae files appear gray until I recolor them in the sdf.
I can see the colors in the dae if I use a program like Meshlab.
I have also presented the problem in this post:
http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/14049/loading-in-cad-model-with-colors/

values.title: Gazebo crashes when receiving (apparently) malformed subscription request

content.raw:
I'm getting a crash when sending a subscription request:

```bash
$ gzserver --verbose nothing-and-rover.world
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 7.0.0
Copyright (C) 2012-2016 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.169
[Err] [msgs.cc:120] EXCEPTION: Can't serialize message of type[gazebo.msgs.Publish] because it is missing required fields

libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type gazebo::common::Exception
Abort trap: 6
$
```
System is MacOS 10.11.6, Gazebo v7.0.0

This is the mesage I send:
```js
// Serialize message and wrap it in Packet
var packet = proto.serialize({
    'stamp': {
        'sec': new Date().now / 1000,
        'nsec': 0,
    },
    'type': 'advertise',
    'serialized_data': proto.serialize(
            'topic': '/gazebo/default/dummy-rover/hokuyo/link/laser/scan',
            'host': NODE_TCP_IP,
            'port': NODE_TCP_PORT,
            'msg_type': 'gazebo.msgs.LaserScanStamped',
        },
        "gazebo.msgs.Subscribe")
}, 'gazebo.msgs.Packet');

// Converting packet size to hex and prepending with zeros
size = padWithZeros(packet.length.toString(16), 8);

// sending packet to 127.0.0.1:11345
socketClient.write(size + packet)
```

Expected result:
Gazebo should print a more detailed description of a problem and **should not crash**.

values.title: error message not shown on console without verbose

content.raw:
I had a problem with a custom plugin which failed to load due to missing libraries. But when running `gzserver` (without enabling verbose output) nothing on the console indicated the problem.

While the information is in the log file and is also show when enabling verbose I find it very intuitive that and error message like that is not shown on the console. Imo errors (and eventually also warnings?) should always also be shown on the console since that it what the user sees first and based on that can investigate further.
content.html:
I had a problem with a custom plugin which failed to load due to missing libraries. But when running gzserver (without enabling verbose output) nothing on the console indicated the problem.

While the information is in the log file and is also show when enabling verbose I find it very intuitive that and error message like that is not shown on the console. Imo errors (and eventually also warnings?) should always also be shown on the console since that it what the user sees first and based on that can investigate further.

content.raw:

The attached file model a suspended block. It should fall to the ground after the joint is being removed.

Tested in Gazebo 7.3.0

values.title: Insert sensors in Model Editor

content.raw:
Support inserting sensors of any type into a link in the model editor. 

Currently, the only way to add a sensor to a model through the model editor is by inserting a  nested model which has the sensor, like in [this](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=guided_b&tut=guided_b3) turtorial.

Also see [this](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/14173/is-there-gui-tool-for-creating-sdf/) question.
content.html:
Support inserting sensors of any type into a link in the model editor.

Currently, the only way to add a sensor to a model through the model editor is by inserting a nested model which has the sensor, like in this turtorial.

Also see this question.

values.title: Flaky seg-fault when detaching HarnessPlugin

content.raw:
The `HarnessPlugin` was added in pull request #2346 released in gazebo 7.3.0. When detaching the harness joint, it can seg-fault due to a race condition. The race condition can be exacerbated by unthrottling the real-time update rate, and can also be avoided by pausing before detaching.

Here is a backtrace of the relevant threads:

content.html:
The HarnessPlugin was added in pull request #2346 released in gazebo 7.3.0. When detaching the harness joint, it can seg-fault due to a race condition. The race condition can be exacerbated by unthrottling the real-time update rate, and can also be avoided by pausing before detaching.

Here is a backtrace of the relevant threads:

World::RunLoop thread that received the seg-fault

Thread 1 (Thread 0x7f584ebfc700 (LWP 19220)):

#1  0x00007f58b347a028 in __GI_abort () at abort.c:89
#2  0x00007f58b346fbf6 in __assert_fail_base (fmt=0x7f58b35c03b8 "%s%s%s:%u: %s%sAssertion `%s' failed.\n%n", assertion=assertion@entry=0x7f584d9f1379 "px != 0", file=file@entry=0x7f584d9f0ef0 "/usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp", line=line@entry=653, function=function@entry=0x7f584d9f2900 <boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::physics::Joint>::operator->() const::__PRETTY_FUNCTION__> "typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::physics::Joint; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::physics::Joint*"...) at assert.c:92

values.title: ImuSensor update connection is broken

content.raw:
I'm trying to write a plugin to connect to ImuSensor updates. It appears that the update callback does not get called until a subscriber subscribes on the topic published by the ImuSensor. This bug has a fairly low-effort workaround, but it is inconsistent with usage of ConnectUpdated for other sensor types (e.g. RaySensor), which do not require a subscriber to connect to sensor updates.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Build the ImuSensorPlugin and uncomment the printout in the callback. You'll also need to change "GetLinearAcceleration" to "LinearAcceleration" #!/osrf/gazebo/src/5c00af97a238e565c7fcdddd712139d19a3ca289/plugins/ImuSensorPlugin.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default
2. Attach the plugin to a model in the world (see this [world file](https://gist.github.com/jacquelinekay/f550080b1bb6aacc87ffdd2e3b600a1d) for an example).
3. Open gazebo with --verbose. The debug messages from the callback will not appear.
4. Open "Topic Visualization" and visualize the IMU topic. The debug messages will start coming in.

Tested on the 7.0.0 debian in Xenial and the nightly debian.
content.html:
I'm trying to write a plugin to connect to ImuSensor updates. It appears that the update callback does not get called until a subscriber subscribes on the topic published by the ImuSensor. This bug has a fairly low-effort workaround, but it is inconsistent with usage of ConnectUpdated for other sensor types (e.g. RaySensor), which do not require a subscriber to connect to sensor updates.

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Build the ImuSensorPlugin and uncomment the printout in the callback. You'll also need to change "GetLinearAcceleration" to "LinearAcceleration" #!/osrf/gazebo/src/5c00af97a238e565c7fcdddd712139d19a3ca289/plugins/ImuSensorPlugin.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default
  2. Attach the plugin to a model in the world (see this world file for an example).
  3. Open gazebo with --verbose. The debug messages from the callback will not appear.
  4. Open "Topic Visualization" and visualize the IMU topic. The debug messages will start coming in.

Tested on the 7.0.0 debian in Xenial and the nightly debian.

values.title: Give user feedback about video format being recorded

content.raw:
This relates to the video recording feature introduced on pull request #2432.

Suggestion: pre-fill the dialog with the file extension. I often forget what I clicked on when I started recording.

It might also be nice to let the user know the extension while recording, maybe in the record button's tooltip? "Recording MP4 video..."
content.html:
This relates to the video recording feature introduced on pull request #2432.

Suggestion: pre-fill the dialog with the file extension. I often forget what I clicked on when I started recording.

It might also be nice to let the user know the extension while recording, maybe in the record button's tooltip? "Recording MP4 video..."

values.title: Flaky seg-fault in simbody portion of REGRESSION_1702_remove_model_scene_nodes

content.raw:
I've been seeing repeatable intermittent seg-faults in the simbody instantiation of the `REGRESSION_1702_remove_model_scene_nodes` test (ie. `PhysicsEngines/Issue1702Test.SpawnDeleteSpawnAgain/2`) on the default branch. It consistently seg-faults in [Visual::GetBoundsHelper](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb6cc0893c9b6b160d46734c4fe9dbcbed1a1656/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Visual.cc-1946) when trying to call `node->_updateBounds()` on the `OgreSceneNode`.

[A full backtrace is here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/b651d1e67c6d2b8676359290ab16c766).

A quick check of recent jenkins results shows the test also failing on the simbody test on gazebo7:

* [console log](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo7-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/70/consoleText)

Any ideas @iche033 ?
content.html:
I've been seeing repeatable intermittent seg-faults in the simbody instantiation of the REGRESSION_1702_remove_model_scene_nodes test (ie. PhysicsEngines/Issue1702Test.SpawnDeleteSpawnAgain/2) on the default branch. It consistently seg-faults in Visual::GetBoundsHelper when trying to call node->_updateBounds() on the OgreSceneNode.

A full backtrace is here.

A quick check of recent jenkins results shows the test also failing on the simbody test on gazebo7:

  • console log

Any ideas @iche033 ?

values.title: Logical camera detects models without collisions

content.raw:
If a model only has a visual, no collision, then it is always detected by the logical camera sensor.



Sample world attached. without the collision of test_model, it will be listed in the logical camera output topic. with the collision, test_model won't be detected.
content.html:
If a model only has a visual, no collision, then it is always detected by the logical camera sensor.

Sample world attached. without the collision of test_model, it will be listed in the logical camera output topic. with the collision, test_model won't be detected.

values.title: INTEGRATION_world_clone test may timeout if system has other gzserver instances

content.raw:
I left a gazebo simulation running in a docker container while running my overnight testing script. The `INTEGRATION_world_clone` test failed via timeout many times. Each time, the `check_test_ran.py` script found a rogue gzserver that had been cloned but not killed. Also, I saw the following console message:

~~~
473: sh: 1: kill: Operation not permitted
~~~

I believe that the `Clone` test doesn't get the correct process id when [calling ps](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb6cc0893c9b6b160d46734c4fe9dbcbed1a1656/test/integration/world_clone.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#world_clone.cc-219) since it just takes the first one given to it. It would be more robust to try to identify which is the correct `gzserver`.
content.html:
I left a gazebo simulation running in a docker container while running my overnight testing script. The INTEGRATION_world_clone test failed via timeout many times. Each time, the check_test_ran.py script found a rogue gzserver that had been cloned but not killed. Also, I saw the following console message:

473: sh: 1: kill: Operation not permitted

I believe that the Clone test doesn't get the correct process id when calling ps since it just takes the first one given to it. It would be more robust to try to identify which is the correct gzserver.

values.title: Incorrect sdf file on saving with duplicated plugin

content.raw:
I created a plugin P in models A and B, with models A and B included in model C. The plugin has some customizable parameters and a ```link``` tag.
Also, on editing the model in Gazebo model editor and saving it back. In the new sdf file,

* The sdf is the complete expanded sdf, not with ```<include><uri>...</uri></include>```. Is this the expected behavior?
* The plugin P occurred in saved sdf only once. The saved file contained the information in the model included last. Maybe this is related to #734? IMO, proper handling of namespaces would(?) resolve this. (at least it should) Is there some progress on #734?
* I specified a parameter in plugin P which shared the same name as a link in model A. The sdf converted ```<name>base</name>``` to ```<name>model_c::base</name>```. Can this be optionally prevented? (conversion of some link specified as parameter to relative address)
content.html:
I created a plugin P in models A and B, with models A and B included in model C. The plugin has some customizable parameters and a link tag. Also, on editing the model in Gazebo model editor and saving it back. In the new sdf file,

  • The sdf is the complete expanded sdf, not with <include><uri>...</uri></include>. Is this the expected behavior?
  • The plugin P occurred in saved sdf only once. The saved file contained the information in the model included last. Maybe this is related to #734? IMO, proper handling of namespaces would(?) resolve this. (at least it should) Is there some progress on #734?
  • I specified a parameter in plugin P which shared the same name as a link in model A. The sdf converted <name>base</name> to <name>model_c::base</name>. Can this be optionally prevented? (conversion of some link specified as parameter to relative address)

values.title: Adding directory to GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH causes shader lib not to be found

content.raw:
Launching Gazebo from the launcher bar of Ubuntu works fine. However, launching the server and client separately result in the following error:

    gzclient: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:653: typename 
    boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const 
    [with T = gazebo::rendering::Camera; typename 
    boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::rendering::Camera*]: Assertion `px 
    != 0' failed.
    Aborted (core dumped)

[This question](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/14283/visual-plugin-crashes-before-its-constructor-executes/) at the Q&A site gives some background. This happens with any world file, even the `empty.world` that comes installed with Gazebo. One week it was working, and the next week, seemingly without any changes, it wasn't. [Edit 9/19/16: As I say in a comment below, what changed, which I forgot about, was that I added lines to .bashrc to modify the GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH environment variable.]

System:  
ubuntu 14.04 LTS  
Intel Core i7-6700 CPU @ 3.40 GHz x 8  
GeForce GTX 980 Ti/PCIe/SSE2  
16 GB RAM

values.title: Disable sensor visualizations from the GUI

content.raw:
It would be nice to have the option to hide sensors. For example, load the PR2, right-click it and uncheck "View sensors". The floating camera image, blue rays, projector lines all disappear.

Like other visualizations, it should be possible to disable it for all models at once from the main menu.

values.title: Heightmap visual without collision causes gzclient black screen

content.raw:
If you open a world file that has a `<visual>` heightmap element without a `<collision>`, it will cause gzclient to hang with a black screen without loading (similar to #681). The following patch can be used to replicate the problem:

~~~
diff -r bb6cc0893c9b worlds/heightmap.world
--- a/worlds/heightmap.world	Thu Aug 25 15:55:30 2016 -0700
+++ b/worlds/heightmap.world	Fri Sep 09 17:02:46 2016 -0700
@@ -96,15 +96,6 @@
     <model name="heightmap">
       <static>true</static>
       <link name="link">
-        <collision name="collision">
-          <geometry>
-            <heightmap>
-              <uri>file://media/materials/textures/heightmap_bowl.png</uri>
-              <size>129 129 10</size>
-              <pos>0 0 0</pos>
-            </heightmap>
-          </geometry>
-        </collision>
         <visual name="visual_abcedf">
           <geometry>
             <heightmap>
~~~

I halted gzclient in gdb and found the following backtrace:

~~~
^C
Program received signal SIGINT, Interrupt.
pthread_cond_wait@@GLIBC_2.3.2 () at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/pthread_cond_wait.S:185
185	in ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/pthread_cond_wait.S
(gdb) bt
#0  pthread_cond_wait@@GLIBC_2.3.2 () at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/pthread_cond_wait.S:185
#1  0x00007ffff5e4f2f3 in wait (m=..., this=0x7ffff6071be0 <g_responseCondition>) at /usr/include/boost/thread/pthread/condition_variable.hpp:73
#2  gazebo::transport::request (_worldName="default", _request="heightmap_data", _data="") at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/transport/TransportIface.cc:220
#3  0x00007ffff5aba428 in gazebo::rendering::Heightmap::Load (this=this@entry=0x181bbb0) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/rendering/Heightmap.cc:371
#4  0x00007ffff5abbb7e in gazebo::rendering::Heightmap::LoadFromMsg (this=0x181bbb0, _msg=...) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/rendering/Heightmap.cc:147
#5  0x00007ffff5afa699 in gazebo::rendering::Scene::ProcessVisualMsg (this=this@entry=0x1861310, _msg=..., _type=<optimized out>) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/rendering/Scene.cc:2758
#6  0x00007ffff5b05f25 in gazebo::rendering::Scene::PreRender (this=0x1861310) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/rendering/Scene.cc:2040
#7  0x00007ffff7648c95 in operator() (this=<optimized out>) at /usr/include/boost/function/function_template.hpp:767
#8  gazebo::event::EventT<void ()>::Signal() (this=<optimized out>) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/common/Event.hh:370
#9  0x00007ffff7641344 in operator() (this=<optimized out>) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/common/Event.hh:214
#10 gazebo::gui::GLWidget::paintEvent (this=0x1846740, _e=0x7fffffffd520) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/gui/GLWidget.cc:277
#11 0x00007ffff27b9300 in QWidget::event(QEvent*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#12 0x00007ffff2769e2c in QApplicationPrivate::notify_helper(QObject*, QEvent*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#13 0x00007ffff27704a0 in QApplication::notify(QObject*, QEvent*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#14 0x00007ffff71b64dd in QCoreApplication::notifyInternal(QObject*, QEvent*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtCore.so.4
#15 0x00007ffff27b3a21 in QWidgetPrivate::drawWidget(QPaintDevice*, QRegion const&, QPoint const&, int, QPainter*, QWidgetBackingStore*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#16 0x00007ffff2974b9b in QWidgetPrivate::repaint_sys(QRegion const&) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#17 0x00007ffff27a8e47 in QWidgetPrivate::syncBackingStore() () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#18 0x00007ffff27b8e7a in QWidget::event(QEvent*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#19 0x00007ffff2769e2c in QApplicationPrivate::notify_helper(QObject*, QEvent*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#20 0x00007ffff27704a0 in QApplication::notify(QObject*, QEvent*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#21 0x00007ffff71b64dd in QCoreApplication::notifyInternal(QObject*, QEvent*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtCore.so.4
#22 0x00007ffff71b9b3d in QCoreApplicationPrivate::sendPostedEvents(QObject*, int, QThreadData*) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtCore.so.4
#23 0x00007ffff71e3f83 in ?? () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtCore.so.4
#24 0x00007fffefdd7e04 in g_main_context_dispatch () from /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libglib-2.0.so.0
#25 0x00007fffefdd8048 in ?? () from /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libglib-2.0.so.0
#26 0x00007fffefdd80ec in g_main_context_iteration () from /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libglib-2.0.so.0
#27 0x00007ffff71e37a1 in QEventDispatcherGlib::processEvents(QFlags<QEventLoop::ProcessEventsFlag>) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtCore.so.4
#28 0x00007ffff280bbe6 in ?? () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtGui.so.4
#29 0x00007ffff71b50af in QEventLoop::processEvents(QFlags<QEventLoop::ProcessEventsFlag>) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtCore.so.4
#30 0x00007ffff71b53a5 in QEventLoop::exec(QFlags<QEventLoop::ProcessEventsFlag>) () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtCore.so.4
#31 0x00007ffff71bab79 in QCoreApplication::exec() () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQtCore.so.4
#32 0x00007ffff76508bb in gazebo::gui::run (_argc=_argc@entry=2, _argv=_argv@entry=0x7fffffffddd8) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/gui/GuiIface.cc:360
#33 0x000000000040152a in main (_argc=2, _argv=0x7fffffffddd8) at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo7-debbuilder/build/gazebo-7.3.1/gazebo/gui/main.cc:25
(gdb)
~~~

It is ultimately blocking on a `gazebo::transport::request` call (type `heightmap_data`) in [rendering::Heightmap::Load](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb6cc0893c9b6b160d46734c4fe9dbcbed1a1656/gazebo/rendering/Heightmap.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Heightmap.cc-357), which was generated by `Scene::PreRender`. Apparently, [physics::HeightmapShape](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bb6cc0893c9b6b160d46734c4fe9dbcbed1a1656/gazebo/physics/HeightmapShape.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#HeightmapShape.cc-70) is the only class that responds to `heightmap_data` requests. Since there is no heightmap `<collision>`, there is no `HeightmapShape` to respond to the request. Also, I believe this design prevents multiple heightmaps from being used, since they would all try to respond to the same `heightmap_data` requests.

values.title: Visual Plugin example crashes if "inserted" into gazebo

content.raw:
The BlinkVisualPlugin example world file works fine if launched as such, but if you extract out the models in it and try to insert them into gazebo, gzclient crashes.

using spawn_model also works fine.

Crash info:
```
in Visual.cc:1158, the call to this->dataPtr->sceneNode->numAttachedObjects()
sceneNode is null (0x0).

relevant bit of trace:
gazebo::rendering::Visual::SetDiffuse()
gazebo::BlinkVisualPlugin::Update()
```

values.title: Gazebo is setting "sensor's last update time" to 0

content.raw:
Hi all,

I found this issue, using ROS, AMCL, TurtleBot Simulation etc. I traced it back to line 191:

    this->depth_sensor_update_time_ = this->parentSensor->LastUpdateTime();

in [gazebo_ros_openni_kinect.cpp](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_openni_kinect.cpp). The parentSensor->LastUpdateTime() is 0 at 50% of the time.

I am using Ubuntu 16.04 LTS and ROS Kinetic with corresponding Gazebo Version 7.0.0. Here is how I reproduced the bug:

    roslaunch turtlebot_gazebo turtlebot_world.launch

This starts gazebo with one turtlebot. For the kinect plugin to send data, you need to subscribe to its ROS topic, because it uses lazy publishing:

    rostopic echo /camera/depth/image_raw/header

This subscribes only to the header of the image message. There you should see, if you can reproduce my issue, that the time stamp is 0 in ~50% of the time. I would expect it to be always the simulation time.

I hope someone could help here, because I didn't want to setup the whole gazebo project from source, in order to further debug it.

Greetings,
  Stephan
content.html:
Hi all,

I found this issue, using ROS, AMCL, TurtleBot Simulation etc. I traced it back to line 191:

this->depth_sensor_update_time_ = this->parentSensor->LastUpdateTime();

in gazebo_ros_openni_kinect.cpp. The parentSensor->LastUpdateTime() is 0 at 50% of the time.

I am using Ubuntu 16.04 LTS and ROS Kinetic with corresponding Gazebo Version 7.0.0. Here is how I reproduced the bug:

roslaunch turtlebot_gazebo turtlebot_world.launch

This starts gazebo with one turtlebot. For the kinect plugin to send data, you need to subscribe to its ROS topic, because it uses lazy publishing:

rostopic echo /camera/depth/image_raw/header

This subscribes only to the header of the image message. There you should see, if you can reproduce my issue, that the time stamp is 0 in ~50% of the time. I would expect it to be always the simulation time.

I hope someone could help here, because I didn't want to setup the whole gazebo project from source, in order to further debug it.

Greetings, Stephan

values.title: Visual messages with transparency cause huge FPS drop after upgrade to Gazebo 7

content.html:
Hi, we recently upgraded from Gazebo 5.1 to 7.3 and had major problems with the FPS in gzclient dropping to 2 FPS while using the same models and plugins which worked fine in 5.1.

By creating a minimal breaking example, I found that the problem is caused by Visual messages with a set transparency value in a populated world.

In the attachment and below you can find my minimal breaking example. It consists of a world of similar complexity to my application in the RoboCup Logistics League and a plugin creating a blinking light with Visual messages.

With Gazebo 7 this runs at 8 FPS. By commenting the line that sets the transparency of the visual msg or downgrading to Gazebo 5.1, this runs above 26 FPS.

I already created a workaround for our application by omitting using transparency, but I think this is a bug you want to fix.

(I am using an Intel Core i7-3770 CPU @ 3.40GHz × 8 and an Intel Corporation Xeon E3-1200 v2/3rd Gen Core processor Graphics Controller with Fedora 23. )

World file:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <world name="RCLL">
    <gui>
      <camera name="user camera">
    <pose>1 -2 9.5 0 1.1 1.56</pose>
      </camera>
    </gui>
    <physics type="ode">
      <max_step_size>0.004</max_step_size>
      <real_time_factor>1</real_time_factor>
      <real_time_update_rate>300</real_time_update_rate>
    </physics>
    <scene>
      <shadows>0</shadows>
    </scene>
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>

    <!-- Added some models to reach a similar complexity -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>0 1 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>0 2 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>1 1 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>1 2 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>2 1 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>2 2 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>3 1 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>3 2 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>4 1 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://youbot</uri>
      <pose>4 2 0.2 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>

    <!-- this plugin causes the FPS drop -->
    <plugin name="breaking_plugin" filename="libbreaking_plugin.so" />
  </world>
</sdf>

Plugin:

#include <gazebo/gazebo.hh>
#include <gazebo/physics/physics.hh>
#include <gazebo/common/common.hh>
#include <gazebo/transport/transport.hh>

using namespace gazebo;

class LightControl : public WorldPlugin
{
public:
  LightControl(){};
  ~LightControl(){};

  virtual void Load(physics::WorldPtr _world, sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)
  {
    world_ = _world;
    update_connection_ = event::Events::ConnectWorldUpdateBegin(boost::bind(&LightControl::OnUpdate, this, _1));
    node_ = transport::NodePtr(new transport::Node());
    node_->Init(world_->GetName());
    visPub_ = this->node_->Advertise<msgs::Visual>("~/visual", /*max number of lights*/ 3*12);
    last_sent_time_ = world_->GetSimTime().Double();
  }

  virtual void OnUpdate(const common::UpdateInfo &)
  {
    double time = world_->GetSimTime().Double();    
    if(time - last_sent_time_ < 0.1)
      return;
    last_sent_time_ = time;

    state_on = !state_on;

    msgs::Visual msg;

    //////////// this line costs ~20 FPS in Gazbeo 7
    msg.set_transparency(0.0);
    ///////////

    msgs::Geometry *geomMsg = msg.mutable_geometry();
    geomMsg->set_type(msgs::Geometry::CYLINDER);
    geomMsg->mutable_cylinder()->set_radius(0.05);
    geomMsg->mutable_cylinder()->set_length(0.1);
    msg.set_cast_shadows(false);
    msg.set_parent_name("light::link");
    msg.set_name("light::link::redon");
#if GAZEBO_MAJOR_VERSION > 5
    msgs::Set(msg.mutable_pose(), ignition::math::Pose3d(1, 0, 0.085, 0, 0, 0));
#else
    msgs::Set(msg.mutable_pose(), math::Pose(1, 0, 0.085, 0, 0, 0));
#endif
    msgs::Set(msg.mutable_material()->mutable_diffuse(), common::Color(0.8, 0, 0, 0.8));
    msgs::Set(msg.mutable_material()->mutable_emissive(), common::Color(1.0, 0.3, 0.3, 1.0));
    if(state_on)
      msg.set_visible(true);
    else
      msg.set_visible(false);
    visPub_->Publish(msg);
  }

private:
  physics::WorldPtr world_;
  event::ConnectionPtr update_connection_;
  transport::NodePtr node_;
  transport::PublisherPtr visPub_;
  double last_sent_time_;
  bool state_on = true;
};

GZ_REGISTER_WORLD_PLUGIN(LightControl)

values.title: Documentation / Installation Instructions

content.raw: There are no "from source" installation guidelines for version 7. The most recent guide I could find was for version 5, where ignition libraries were not separated, causing problems when I went to build. There should be install-from-source instructions in the README.
content.html: There are no "from source" installation guidelines for version 7. The most recent guide I could find was for version 5, where ignition libraries were not separated, causing problems when I went to build. There should be install-from-source instructions in the README.

values.title: Topic name mismatch on heavy worlds with custom names

content.raw: When loading a heavy world with a custom name, it seems that some topics are mistakenly created under `/gazebo/default`, while others are correctly created under `/gazebo/custom_name`

~~~

values.title: Saved world doesn't keep light colors

content.raw:
1. Insert a light into the world

1. From the left panel, change the light's color

1. File -> Save World As

1. Close Gazebo and open the saved world

1. The light color is wrong.
content.html:
1. Insert a light into the world

  2. From the left panel, change the light's color

  3. File -> Save World As

  4. Close Gazebo and open the saved world

  5. The light color is wrong.

values.title: Use CLOCK_MONOTONIC in Sleep and timer functions

content.raw:
The `Time::Sleep` function on Linux uses [clock_nanosleep(CLOCK_REALTIME, ...)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/73fae73d688a67241403ed58636f5da0fd72e314/gazebo/common/Time.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Time.cc-427), which is based on the system clock, which can jitter if changed by ntp ([see stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/3527632)). Using `CLOCK_MONOTONIC` would provide more consistent timing.

IssueForNewDevelopers
content.html:
The Time::Sleep function on Linux uses clock_nanosleep(CLOCK_REALTIME, ...), which is based on the system clock, which can jitter if changed by ntp (see stackoverflow). Using CLOCK_MONOTONIC would provide more consistent timing.

IssueForNewDevelopers

values.title: Plotting doesn't work for multiple Gazebos running in parallel

content.raw:
1. In one terminal, run: `gazebo worlds/shapes.world`

1. On another terminal: `export GAZEBO_MASTER_URI=http://localhost:11346; gazebo worlds/simple_arm.world`

1. Open the plot window for both gzclients, both will have the same models in the Models tab, but they should be different
content.html:
1. In one terminal, run: gazebo worlds/shapes.world

  2. On another terminal: export GAZEBO_MASTER_URI=http://localhost:11346; gazebo worlds/simple_arm.world

  3. Open the plot window for both gzclients, both will have the same models in the Models tab, but they should be different

values.title: gz topic -e doesn't wait for messages to be published

content.raw:
for version 7.3.1, and when built from source, `gz topic -e /gazebo/deafult/valkyrie/joint_cmd` claims ``[Err] [gz_topic.cc:190] Unable to get message type for topic[/gazebo/default/valkyrie/joint_cmd]`

steps to reproduce:

    gazebo --verbose worlds/cart_demo.world
    gz topic --verbose -e /gazebo/default/test_model/joint_cmd #omit --verbose if using 7.3.1

values.title: Problem with SonarSensor in dart5

content.raw:
The `SonarSensor_TEST` [passes with gazebo7 and dart 4.3](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/98/testReport/(root)/SonarTests_SonarSensor_TEST/), though it is failing with the current integration with dart5 (see [recent jenkins result](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia_docker/27/testReport/junit/(root)/UNIT_SonarSensor_TEST/test_ran/) and discussion of pull request #1825).

The test is seg-faulting when running the `DemoWorld` subtest with dart. It seems to be related to trying to create a mesh for the sonar sensor without telling it to which body it is attached (see also this [dart issue](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/114).

~~~
