[Dbg] [SonarSensor_TEST.cc:197] Physics dart paused 0
[New Thread 0x7fffd21c8700 (LWP 8039)]
[New Thread 0x7fffd19c7700 (LWP 8041)]
[New Thread 0x7fffd11c6700 (LWP 8044)]
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.91
***** Internal Program Error - assertion (_collision->GetDARTBodyNode()) failed in void gazebo::physics::DARTMesh::CreateMesh(float*, int*, unsigned int, unsigned int, gazebo::physics::DARTCollisionPtr, const gazebo::math::Vector3&):
gazebo/physics/dart/DARTMesh.cc(151): DART _collision->GetDARTBodyNode() is null

Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.
[Switching to Thread 0x7fffd21c8700 (LWP 8039)]
0x00007ffff4934c37 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
56    ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c: No such file or directory.
(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007ffff4934c37 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
#1  0x00007ffff4938028 in __GI_abort () at abort.c:89

content.html:
The SonarSensor_TEST passes with gazebo7 and dart 4.3, though it is failing with the current integration with dart5 (see recent jenkins result and discussion of pull request #1825).

The test is seg-faulting when running the DemoWorld subtest with dart. It seems to be related to trying to create a mesh for the sonar sensor without telling it to which body it is attached (see also this dart issue.

values.title: Plugin for triggering single sensor update

content.raw: There is a group using ROS that would like to be able to trigger sensor updates (for a stereo camera for example) rather than receive a continuous stream of sensor readings. I believe this is possible by setting the `always_on` sdf parameter to false and calling `sensor->Update(true)`. We could expose the trigger on a gazebo or ROS topic. I'm wondering if anyone has done this before?
content.html: There is a group using ROS that would like to be able to trigger sensor updates (for a stereo camera for example) rather than receive a continuous stream of sensor readings. I believe this is possible by setting the always_on sdf parameter to false and calling sensor->Update(true). We could expose the trigger on a gazebo or ROS topic. I'm wondering if anyone has done this before?

values.title: Changing the clipping distance for the UserCamera

content.raw: The clipping distances for camera sensors can be changed via [sdf parameters](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/a3fa3d1163cc2fe991ac106e51695b99f8b119ca/sdf/1.6/camera.sdf?fileviewer=file-view-default#camera.sdf-25), but I don't see any way to change the clipping distances for the UserCamera. It would be nice to be able to set this from gzclient or from the `<gui>` element in a world file.
content.html: The clipping distances for camera sensors can be changed via sdf parameters, but I don't see any way to change the clipping distances for the UserCamera. It would be nice to be able to set this from gzclient or from the <gui> element in a world file.

values.title: Model Editor crashes if swap joint child-parent is used

1. Enter model editor

1. Insert 2 links

1. Open joint creation dialog

1. Click on one link for child, the other for parent

1. Then click on the swap button to swap parent and child

1. Create the joint

1. Ctrl+X to exit the editor, choose to save

1. Enter model editor

  2. Insert 2 links

  3. Open joint creation dialog

  7. Ctrl+X to exit the editor, choose to save

values.title: Underwater - added mass

content.raw:
Hi,

Is there an implementation of hydrodynamics effect for underwater vehicles? 
Particularly the [added mass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Added_mass) and the fluid inertial forces?

I'd like to consider an added mass on my vehicle like a 6x6 matrix, to be taken in account altogether with the vehicle inertial ([m*eye(3x3), zeros(3x3); zeros(3x3), I]).
content.html:
Hi,

Is there an implementation of hydrodynamics effect for underwater vehicles? Particularly the added mass and the fluid inertial forces?

I'd like to consider an added mass on my vehicle like a 6x6 matrix, to be taken in account altogether with the vehicle inertial ([m*eye(3x3), zeros(3x3); zeros(3x3), I]).

values.title: Accessing accumulated forces

content.raw:
Is it possible to have access to the accumulated forces in a link, by `dBodyGetForce/Torque`, before the forces/torques are applied?

I want to edit the efforts before they are applied in the link. Like it is proposed in [`ConnectBeforePhysicsUpdate`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/f30d4a01ce946b9940388cef13d53f8ac75cc7d7/gazebo/common/Events.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Events.hh-172).

It seems to me that one can only have access to the forces that are applied in the previous step, by `Link::GetWorldForce`, is that rigth?
content.html:
Is it possible to have access to the accumulated forces in a link, by dBodyGetForce/Torque, before the forces/torques are applied?

I want to edit the efforts before they are applied in the link. Like it is proposed in ConnectBeforePhysicsUpdate.

It seems to me that one can only have access to the forces that are applied in the previous step, by Link::GetWorldForce, is that rigth?

values.title: Factory messages aren't always received in gzTest.Model

content.raw:
I've been looking into the `gzTest.Model` failures in `UNIT_gz_TEST`, which fail very frequently on homebrew. I have made some improvements in the [gz_test_race branch](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/gz_test_race%0Dgazebo7), but there is still one flaky failure that I can't figure out.

[This gazebo7 homebrew build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo7-homebrew-amd64/84/console) has the test failing twice with the following console output:

~~~
515: [ RUN      ] gzTest.Model
515: [Msg] Waiting for master.
515: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
515: [Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.252
515: tools/gz_TEST.cc:325: Failure
515: Value of: g_msgDebugOut.empty()
515:   Actual: true
515: Expected: false
515: tools/gz_TEST.cc:340: Failure
515: Value of: msg.DebugString()
515:   Actual: "sdf: \"<?xml version=\\'1.0\\'?>\\n<sdf version=\\'1.6\\'>\\n  <model name=\\'my_box\\'>\\n    <pose frame=\\'\\'>0 0 0.5 0 -0 0</pose>\\n    <link name=\\'link\\'>\\n      <collision name=\\'collision\\'>\\n        <geometry>\\n          <box>\\n            <size>1 1 1</size>\\n          </box>\\n        </geometry>\\n      </collision>\\n      <visual name=\\'visual\\'>\\n        <geometry>\\n          <box>\\n            <size>1 1 1</size>\\n          </box>\\n        </geometry>\\n        <material>\\n          <script>\\n            <uri>__default__</uri>\\n            <name>__default__</name>\\n          </script>\\n        </material>\\n      </visual>\\n    </link>\\n  </model>\\n</sdf>\\n\"\npose {\n  position {\n    x: 0\n    y: 0\n    z: 0\n  }\n  orientation {\n    x: 0\n    y: 0\n    z: 0\n    w: 1\n  }\n}\n"
515: Expected: g_msgDebugOut
515: Which is: ""
515: tools/gz_TEST.cc:462: Failure
515: Expected: (g_msgDebugOut.find("simple_arm")) != (std::string::npos), actual: 18446744073709551615 vs 18446744073709551615
515: [  FAILED  ] gzTest.Model (7045 ms)
~~~

~~~
515: [ RUN      ] gzTest.Model
515: [Msg] Waiting for master.
515: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
515: [Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.252
515: tools/gz_TEST.cc:325: Failure
515: Value of: g_msgDebugOut.empty()
515:   Actual: true
515: Expected: false
515: tools/gz_TEST.cc:340: Failure
515: Value of: msg.DebugString()
515:   Actual: "sdf: \"<?xml version=\\'1.0\\'?>\\n<sdf version=\\'1.6\\'>\\n  <model name=\\'my_box\\'>\\n    <pose frame=\\'\\'>0 0 0.5 0 -0 0</pose>\\n    <link name=\\'link\\'>\\n      <collision name=\\'collision\\'>\\n        <geometry>\\n          <box>\\n            <size>1 1 1</size>\\n          </box>\\n        </geometry>\\n      </collision>\\n      <visual name=\\'visual\\'>\\n        <geometry>\\n          <box>\\n            <size>1 1 1</size>\\n          </box>\\n        </geometry>\\n        <material>\\n          <script>\\n            <uri>__default__</uri>\\n            <name>__default__</name>\\n          </script>\\n        </material>\\n      </visual>\\n    </link>\\n  </model>\\n</sdf>\\n\"\npose {\n  position {\n    x: 0\n    y: 0\n    z: 0\n  }\n  orientation {\n    x: 0\n    y: 0\n    z: 0\n    w: 1\n  }\n}\n"
515: Expected: g_msgDebugOut
515: Which is: ""
515: tools/gz_TEST.cc:389: Failure
515: Value of: g_msgDebugOut.empty()
515:   Actual: true
515: Expected: false
515: tools/gz_TEST.cc:404: Failure
515: Value of: msg.DebugString()
515:   Actual: "sdf: \"<?xml version=\\'1.0\\'?>\\n<sdf version=\\'1.6\\'>\\n  <model name=\\'my_box\\'>\\n    <pose frame=\\'\\'>0 0 0.5 0 -0 0</pose>\\n    <link name=\\'link\\'>\\n      <collision name=\\'collision\\'>\\n        <geometry>\\n          <box>\\n            <size>1 1 1</size>\\n          </box>\\n        </geometry>\\n      </collision>\\n      <visual name=\\'visual\\'>\\n        <geometry>\\n          <box>\\n            <size>1 1 1</size>\\n          </box>\\n        </geometry>\\n        <material>\\n          <script>\\n            <uri>__default__</uri>\\n            <name>__default__</name>\\n          </script>\\n        </material>\\n      </visual>\\n    </link>\\n  </model>\\n</sdf>\\n\"\npose {\n  position {\n    x: 0\n    y: 0\n    z: 0\n  }\n  orientation {\n    x: 0\n    y: 0\n    z: 0\n    w: 1\n  }\n}\n"
515: Expected: g_msgDebugOut
515: Which is: ""
515: [  FAILED  ] gzTest.Model (7623 ms)
~~~

Ignoring the failed expectation at line 462, since that is fixed in the `gz_test_race` branch, there are failure at lines 325/340 twice and 389/404 once. Each of these expectations involves invoking `gz model` to spawn a `my_box` model and waiting for a subscriber to `~/factory` to receive the message. These expectations usually pass on my Ubuntu machine, but usually fail on homebrew. The strange thing is that there are other expectations that get model info and pass, so the model must exist. It seems that the only thing failing is the receipt of the `~/factory` by the gtest executable.

values.title: ForceTorquePlugin subclass never instantiates

content.raw:
I was unable to get my force-torque sensor plugin working until I stopped trying to subclass from ForceTorquePlugin and just directly subclassed the SensorPlugin class. In particular, the constructor never executed. This was the only change made to the class to get it working.

Gazebo 7.3.1
Ubuntu 16.04
content.html:
I was unable to get my force-torque sensor plugin working until I stopped trying to subclass from ForceTorquePlugin and just directly subclassed the SensorPlugin class. In particular, the constructor never executed. This was the only change made to the class to get it working.

Gazebo 7.3.1 Ubuntu 16.04

values.title: Gazebo cannot handle collada files as collision mesh

content.raw:
Hi

I created a collada mesh (Floorplan.dae) which drives gazebo crazy. It is loadable and gazebo does not crash, but when I spawn a TurtleBot on it, the TurtleBot gets twisting wheels and is hovering and hopping around. 

Here are some more details: http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/14591/why-does-my-custom-collada-mesh-makes-the-turtlebot-wheels-twist/

I am using Gazebo 7.0.0 with ROS Kinetic under Ubuntu 16.04 LTS.

The collada file in question is attached.

Greetings,
  Stephan

values.title: model include tag with pose could confuse model construction

content.raw:
a model like this one

~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <world name="default">
    <!-- A global light source -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <!-- A ground plane -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>

    <model name="test_rotate">
      <pose>0 0 0 0 0 -1.5708</pose>
      <include>
        <uri>model://zephyr_delta_wing</uri>
        <pose>0 0 0 0 0 1.5708</pose>
      </include>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
~~~

results in confused model orientation, where joints are not aligned correctly anymore

![confused_model.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1285370966-confused_model.png)

I suspect something to do with [this bit of code](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/fe6140e1f319f0b5660bdac9a5a6f33e306b12d6/gazebo/physics/Entity.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Entity.cc-625)?

<sdf version="1.4">

      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <!-- A ground plane -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>

    <model name="test_rotate">
      <pose>0 0 0 0 0 -1.5708</pose>
      <include>
        <uri>model://zephyr_delta_wing</uri>
        <pose>0 0 0 0 0 1.5708</pose>
      </include>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

results in confused model orientation, where joints are not aligned correctly anymore

I suspect something to do with this bit of code?

values.title: Can't set important para parameter is SonarSensor class and RaySensor by code

content.raw:
From documentation, I see that the user can't modify MaxRange, MinRange and Radius of SonarSensor class. The system just allow to set this itens from xml using the Sensor plugin ready.

Similar thing happens with RaySensor class.

Similar thing happens with RaySensor class.

values.title: Heightmap collision problems in bullet

content.raw:
Found two problemns:

1. running `gzserver -e bullet worlds/heightmap.world` results in a segfault after some time (<1sec). The heightmap integration test passes probably because it only runs for a few iterations


1. loading a dem heightmap works (e.g. `heightmap_dem.world`) but there are no collisions. A box fill fall straight through the heightmap.
content.html:
Found two problemns:

  1. running gzserver -e bullet worlds/heightmap.world results in a segfault after some time (<1sec). The heightmap integration test passes probably because it only runs for a few iterations

  2. loading a dem heightmap works (e.g. heightmap_dem.world) but there are no collisions. A box fill fall straight through the heightmap.

values.title: Add timeout to synchronous transport::request

content.html:
As it is now, it will hang forever if no one replies to the request.

A possible implementation:

diff -r ff4e2ba985d6 gazebo/transport/TransportIface.cc
--- a/gazebo/transport/TransportIface.cc    Mon Oct 24 11:05:19 2016 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/transport/TransportIface.cc    Tue Oct 25 10:28:57 2016 -0700
@@ -193,7 +193,7 @@
 /////////////////////////////////////////////////
 boost::shared_ptr<msgs::Response> transport::request(
     const std::string &_worldName, const std::string &_request,
-    const std::string &_data)
+    const std::string &_data, const common::Time &_timeout)
 {
   msgs::Request *request = msgs::CreateRequest(_request, _data);

@@ -214,7 +214,9 @@
   std::list<boost::shared_ptr<msgs::Response> >::iterator iter;

   bool valid = false;
-  while (!valid && !g_stopped)
+  auto startTime = common::Time::GetWallTime();
+  while (!valid && !g_stopped &&
+      common::Time::GetWallTime() - startTime < _timeout)
   {
     // Wait for a response
     g_responseCondition.wait(lock);
diff -r ff4e2ba985d6 gazebo/transport/TransportIface.hh
--- a/gazebo/transport/TransportIface.hh    Mon Oct 24 11:05:19 2016 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/transport/TransportIface.hh    Tue Oct 25 10:28:57 2016 -0700
@@ -92,16 +92,18 @@
     void pause_incoming(bool _pause);

     /// \brief Send a request and receive a response.  This call will block
-    /// until a response is received.
+    /// until a response is received or timeout is reached.
     /// \param[in] _worldName The name of the world to which the request
     /// should be sent
     /// \param[in] _request The type request.
     /// \param[in] _data Optional data string.
+    /// \param[in] _data Optional timeout, 10 s by default.
     /// \return The response to the request.  Can be empty.
     GZ_TRANSPORT_VISIBLE
     boost::shared_ptr<msgs::Response> request(const std::string &_worldName,
-                                              const std::string &_request,
-                                              const std::string &_data = "");
+        const std::string &_request,
+        const std::string &_data = "",
+        const common::Time &_timeout = common::Time(10));

     /// \brief Send a request and don't wait for a response. This is
     /// non-blocking.

IssueForNewDevelopers

values.title: gzserver hang during shutdown

content.raw:
Recently, gzserver has been less responsive to `Ctrl+C`. I recently attached to a hanging process (running [test/worlds/revolute_joint_test.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/192a57657ec0d4873f695a3dec026064aec0240e/test/worlds/revolute_joint_test.world?fileviewer=file-view-default)) and got a backtrace showing that it is stuck in an infinite loop in `Publisher::Fini`:

~~~
(gdb) bt
#0  __clock_nanosleep (clock_id=0, flags=0, req=0x7ffd5d1a9040, rem=0xffffffffffffffff) at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/clock_nanosleep.c:49
#1  0x00007f2cbad3c393 in gazebo::common::Time::Sleep (_time=...) at /data_fast/scpeters/ws/gazebo7/src/gazebo/gazebo/common/Time.cc:427
#2  0x00007f2cbad3c557 in gazebo::common::Time::MSleep (_ms=_ms@entry=10) at /data_fast/scpeters/ws/gazebo7/src/gazebo/gazebo/common/Time.cc:446

content.html:
Recently, gzserver has been less responsive to Ctrl+C. I recently attached to a hanging process (running test/worlds/revolute_joint_test.world) and got a backtrace showing that it is stuck in an infinite loop in Publisher::Fini:

values.title: wrench topic prints incorrectly

content.raw:
I'm building from source (at 192a57657ec0), and I've just noticed that `gz topic -e` on a wrench gives something very weird. It looks like it's skipping the x field, and printing some pointer instead?

```
gz topic -e /gazebo/default/table/link/wrench 
force {
  y: 0
  z: 0
  4: 0x0000000000000000
}
torque {
  y: 0
  z: 0
  4: 0x0000000000000000
}

```

steps to reproduce:

 1. launch gazebo and insert any model
 1. apply a force via the gui (can be zero)
 1. `gz topic -e /gazebo/default/your_model/wrench`
 1. apply a force again, check the output of gz topic
content.html:
I'm building from source (at 192a57657ec0), and I've just noticed that gz topic -e on a wrench gives something very weird. It looks like it's skipping the x field, and printing some pointer instead?

gz topic -e /gazebo/default/table/link/wrench 
force {
  y: 0
  z: 0
  4: 0x0000000000000000
}
torque {
  y: 0
  z: 0
  4: 0x0000000000000000
}

steps to reproduce:

  1. launch gazebo and insert any model
  2. apply a force via the gui (can be zero)
  3. gz topic -e /gazebo/default/your_model/wrench
  4. apply a force again, check the output of gz topic

values.title: Client terminates on load/start

I run Mac OS X El Capitan

I open gazebo server via Docker with an empty world. Then I try to connect to the server via gzclient that is on my machine.

I run Mac OS X El Capitan

The client fails to start with the following error:

libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type boost::exception_detail::clone_impl<boost::exception_detail::error_info_injector<boost::lock_error> >: boost: mutex lock failed in pthread_mutex_lock: Invalid argument
[1]    71268 abort      gzclient

values.title: Model class uses clock time to wait for sensors, not simulation time

content.raw:
There's a "feature" in the Model class where it waits 5 seconds for sensors to be initialized, but it's using wall clock time. That means models will inconsistently fail to load if simulation slows down (IE, the same model works on your desktop but fails on your laptop. Vey frustrating!). I propose to use gazebo clock time instead to account for slower simulations, since I believe sensors being initialized is a function of that.

I plan to make the patch for this, but I need someone to point me in the right direction. In this case, how should I access gazebo simulation time within gazebo? Subscribing to time seems like the wrong way. Is there something within gazebo (common::Time?) to do this easily?
content.html:
There's a "feature" in the Model class where it waits 5 seconds for sensors to be initialized, but it's using wall clock time. That means models will inconsistently fail to load if simulation slows down (IE, the same model works on your desktop but fails on your laptop. Vey frustrating!). I propose to use gazebo clock time instead to account for slower simulations, since I believe sensors being initialized is a function of that.

I plan to make the patch for this, but I need someone to point me in the right direction. In this case, how should I access gazebo simulation time within gazebo? Subscribing to time seems like the wrong way. Is there something within gazebo (common::Time?) to do this easily?

values.title: XML_NO_ERROR has been removed in tinyxml2 v4.0.0

content.raw: On Arch linux, the gazebo aur package fails to build because I have tinyxml2 v4, which removes the XML_NO_ERROR enum value.  Instead, the XML_SUCCESS value should be used, which has been in tinyxml2 for a while.  I'd be happy to work on a pull request to fix this.
content.html: On Arch linux, the gazebo aur package fails to build because I have tinyxml2 v4, which removes the XML_NO_ERROR enum value. Instead, the XML_SUCCESS value should be used, which has been in tinyxml2 for a while. I'd be happy to work on a pull request to fix this.

values.title: Point and directional light properties wrong after inserting a spot light

content.raw:
1. Open Gazebo
1. On the left panel, click on the `sun`: the properties don't include "spot light"
1. Insert a spot light
1. On the panel, sect `user_spot_light_0`: the properties include "spot light"
1. Select `sun`, and now it also has "spot llight," but it shouldn't
content.html:
1. Open Gazebo
  2. On the left panel, click on the sun: the properties don't include "spot light"
  3. Insert a spot light
  4. On the panel, sect user_spot_light_0: the properties include "spot light"
  5. Select sun, and now it also has "spot llight," but it shouldn't

values.title: JointController doesn't work

content.raw:
Hi, 
I created a simple robot model using urdf. In the urdf, there is a prismatic joint, which is supposed to move a link (a small box) vertically for position control.

joint values in urdf file : type="prismatic" limit effort="1000.0" lower="0" upper="2" velocity="1"

To move it vertically, I wrote a ROS aware gazebo plugin that takes the target position via ROS message. Then I used getJointController to move it like this:

my_model_->GetJointController()->SetPositionTarget(myJointName, 1.2);

my_model_->GetJointController()->SetPositionPID(myJointName, common::PID(2, 0, 1));

I just give a position target and filled the pid. not involved in effort, force or torque.

I tried my code in 2 different setup.

virtualbox - ubuntu 16 - ros kinetic - gazebo 7.0
virtualbox - ubuntu 16 - ros kinetic - gazebo 7.4
the code run on gazebo 7.0 without error and able to move the link as I wanted.

the code run on gazebo 7.4 without error but nothing moved.

Am I missing something or could it be related to a gazebo 7.4 issue ?
content.html:
Hi, I created a simple robot model using urdf. In the urdf, there is a prismatic joint, which is supposed to move a link (a small box) vertically for position control.

joint values in urdf file : type="prismatic" limit effort="1000.0" lower="0" upper="2" velocity="1"

To move it vertically, I wrote a ROS aware gazebo plugin that takes the target position via ROS message. Then I used getJointController to move it like this:

my_model_->GetJointController()->SetPositionTarget(myJointName, 1.2);

my_model_->GetJointController()->SetPositionPID(myJointName, common::PID(2, 0, 1));

I just give a position target and filled the pid. not involved in effort, force or torque.

I tried my code in 2 different setup.

virtualbox - ubuntu 16 - ros kinetic - gazebo 7.0 virtualbox - ubuntu 16 - ros kinetic - gazebo 7.4 the code run on gazebo 7.0 without error and able to move the link as I wanted.

the code run on gazebo 7.4 without error but nothing moved.

Am I missing something or could it be related to a gazebo 7.4 issue ?

values.title: connection to the WorldUpdateBegin event seens not working on Windows version

content.raw: I created a simple plugin to write some logs during the update callback and nothing is working. Only the Load method was executed. I guess there is something strange with the command  event::Events::ConnectWorldUpdateBegin...
content.html: I created a simple plugin to write some logs during the update callback and nothing is working. Only the Load method was executed. I guess there is something strange with the command event::Events::ConnectWorldUpdateBegin...

values.title: Incorrect model visual and collision bounding box

content.raw:
Both `physics::Model::GetBoundingBox()` and `physics::Model::GetCollisionBoundingBox()` return the same, incorrect value.

The box returned in both calls matches the collision box of the last collision element in the last link specified in SDF.

Note that the visual box in Gazebo is rendered correctly.

Issue #1205 tried to point to this problem, but was left unsolved and closed when mistakenly taken as a duplicate of Issue #841.
content.html:
Both physics::Model::GetBoundingBox() and physics::Model::GetCollisionBoundingBox() return the same, incorrect value.

The box returned in both calls matches the collision box of the last collision element in the last link specified in SDF.

Note that the visual box in Gazebo is rendered correctly.

Issue #1205 tried to point to this problem, but was left unsolved and closed when mistakenly taken as a duplicate of Issue #841.

values.title: How can I check which revision is released on apt?

content.raw:
In current ROS shadow fixed apt release, the version of `gazebo5` is `5.0.1+dfsg-1osrf2~trusty2`.
How can we check the revision of this repository which is the same as apt released version?
content.html: In current ROS shadow fixed apt release, the version of gazebo5 is 5.0.1+dfsg-1osrf2~trusty2. How can we check the revision of this repository which is the same as apt released version?

values.title: DARTJoint::SetForce behaves differently from other engines

content.raw:
When creating the `INTEGRATION_keys_to_joints` test for pull request #2490, I noticed that while a joint starts moving for all other engines after one call to `SetForce`, DART requires a few calls until the joint starts moving. 

To reproduce, open `test/worlds/keys_to_joints.world` from that pull request using different engines, and see how only DART takes a while to respond when pressing `o` and `l`.
content.html:
When creating the INTEGRATION_keys_to_joints test for pull request #2490, I noticed that while a joint starts moving for all other engines after one call to SetForce, DART requires a few calls until the joint starts moving.

To reproduce, open test/worlds/keys_to_joints.world from that pull request using different engines, and see how only DART takes a while to respond when pressing o and l.

values.title: Simbody crash on Joint::SetForce

content.raw:
While implementing  the `INTEGRATION_keys_to_joints` test for pull request #2490 I noticed that calling `SimbodyJoint::SetForce` results in crashes with a few different errors for each run.

Some of the errors I got:

~~~
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'SimTK::Exception::StageTooLow'
  what():  SimTK Exception thrown at StateImpl.h:1667:
  Expected stage to be at least Dynamics in StateImpl::getCacheEntry() but current stage was Velocity
~~~

~~~
gzserver: /tmp/buildd/simbody-3.5.1/SimTKcommon/Simulation/src/State.cpp:471: void SimTK::StateImpl::advanceSystemToStage(SimTK::Stage) const: Assertion `allSubsystemsAtLeastAtStage(stg)' failed.
~~~

~~~
gzserver: /tmp/buildd/simbody-3.5.1/SimTKcommon/Simulation/include/SimTKcommon/internal/StateImpl.h:410: void SimTK::PerSubsystemInfo::advanceToStage(SimTK::Stage) const: Assertion `currentStage == g.prev()' failed.
~~~

To reproduce, open `test/worlds/keys_to_joints.world` from that pull request using Simbody, press `o` and/or `l` a few times and get the crash.
content.html:
While implementing the INTEGRATION_keys_to_joints test for pull request #2490 I noticed that calling SimbodyJoint::SetForce results in crashes with a few different errors for each run.

Some of the errors I got:

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'SimTK::Exception::StageTooLow'
  what():  SimTK Exception thrown at StateImpl.h:1667:
  Expected stage to be at least Dynamics in StateImpl::getCacheEntry() but current stage was Velocity

gzserver: /tmp/buildd/simbody-3.5.1/SimTKcommon/Simulation/src/State.cpp:471: void SimTK::StateImpl::advanceSystemToStage(SimTK::Stage) const: Assertion `allSubsystemsAtLeastAtStage(stg)' failed.

gzserver: /tmp/buildd/simbody-3.5.1/SimTKcommon/Simulation/include/SimTKcommon/internal/StateImpl.h:410: void SimTK::PerSubsystemInfo::advanceToStage(SimTK::Stage) const: Assertion `currentStage == g.prev()' failed.

To reproduce, open test/worlds/keys_to_joints.world from that pull request using Simbody, press o and/or l a few times and get the crash.

values.title: Sensor data topics: noise and noise free simultaneously

content.raw: Sensors could potentially output data on two topics, one which contains noise and one that does not. This would require a change to SDF and how noise is applied to sensor data.
content.html: Sensors could potentially output data on two topics, one which contains noise and one that does not. This would require a change to SDF and how noise is applied to sensor data.

values.title: Improve API documentation Link::GetRelativeLinearAccel

content.raw:
It took me quite a while to realize that `Link::GetRelativeLinearAccel()` is not the same as the derivative of linear body velocity, once the coriolis and centripetal terms are not considered. 
The same for `Link::GetRelativeForce()` `Link::GetRelativeTorque()`.

May be the case to put it explicit in API documentation that the above methods do not take in account coriolis and centripetal terms.
Also create a method to return the derivative of linear body velocity
content.html:
It took me quite a while to realize that Link::GetRelativeLinearAccel() is not the same as the derivative of linear body velocity, once the coriolis and centripetal terms are not considered. The same for Link::GetRelativeForce() Link::GetRelativeTorque().

May be the case to put it explicit in API documentation that the above methods do not take in account coriolis and centripetal terms. Also create a method to return the derivative of linear body velocity

values.title: wideanglecamera sensor renders incorrect background color

content.raw:
Images rendered with the wideanglecamera sensor always have a grey background, irrespective of what the <scene><background> tag is set to. See 
[http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/14833/background-color-with-wideanglecamera-sensor/](Link URL)
for example images.
content.html: Images rendered with the wideanglecamera sensor always have a grey background, irrespective of what the <scene><background> tag is set to. See http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/14833/background-color-with-wideanglecamera-sensor/ for example images.

values.title: Add Force and Impulse C++ API to JointController

content.raw: The `Joint::SetForce` API is not thread-safe (see #2092). A remedy is to use the mechanism for applying forces in the `JointController`, but this doesn't have a c++ API. So we should add a C++ API for applying persistent forces (actually we should call them efforts). We could add an API for impulses while we're at it.
content.html: The Joint::SetForce API is not thread-safe (see #2092). A remedy is to use the mechanism for applying forces in the JointController, but this doesn't have a c++ API. So we should add a C++ API for applying persistent forces (actually we should call them efforts). We could add an API for impulses while we're at it.
